Among them, some took refuge in the Buddha, some in the Dharma, and some in the Sangha of monks;
some knelt for a long time, some received the precepts, some attained the stage of stream-enterer, some attained the stage of once-returner, and some attained the stage of non-returner.
At that time, the people all had doubts in their minds, wondering what causes and conditions led to abandoning the household life for the Way, and there was also contention.

The Buddha immediately knew that the disciples had doubts, so he transformed into a Buddha, with a straight face, the thirty-two marks, wearing Dharma robes, and his disciples were also able to transform into people.
The transformed person spoke, and the disciples also spoke;
when the Buddha spoke, the transformed person was silent, and when the transformed person spoke, the Buddha was silent.
Why is this?
Because the right enlightenment is the right intention of the straight path.
The transformed Buddha then touched his right knee to the ground, joined his palms towards the Buddha, and asked in verse:
From where do disputes and changes arise?
Causing worry and pain, slandering each other, and engaging in false speech - please tell us where this originally arises from.
Sitting in worry, disputes arise, and jealousy causes worry and pain.
Desiring to slander each other, false speech arises, and the basis for disputes and slander is established.
